1040694291520278528.text: Our desk kept a spreadsheet of all convert deals in the U.S., and it went through September 2008, and then the next entry was like March 2009. We could have just stayed home for that whole time. Why didn't we, I sometimes wonder.

1040692718027137024.text: Btw one thing that I sometimes wonder about, looking back on it, is: What did I *do* all day in the months immediately after Lehman? There were essentially no deals for like six months. It must have been a whole lot of looking busy.

1040687601160806400.text: We actually did the deal a few months later, which was still not a market to sell convertibles into, but what can you do.

1040687553798701056.text: So my feelings #WhenLehmanCollapsed were a mix of fear that the world was ending, puzzlement that no one else around me seemed worried, and -  mostly - selfish relief that my deal was off and no one would call me on vacation.

1040687446269349888.text: By the time I finished the memo on Friday, everyone was like "ha yeah this deal is not going next week is it." It was already not a market to sell convertibles into. But I sent it off, went to California, and woke up in Napa on Monday to the news of Lehman's bankruptcy.

1040687360026071040.text: But I had a long-scheduled vacation in California that week. So I found someone to cover and spent the week before downloading everything I knew about the deal into like a 20-page memo with flowcharts, footnotes, etc.

1040687333232787456.text: I have told my #WhenLehmanCollapsed story before, but basically I was working on a complicated deal that had been pushed back to go on, like, September 17 or something.
